page.title: 18 BRYNDRAENOG
page.content: Bryndraenog, now owned by Mr. & Mrs C. Thomas, was built in the fifteenth century and is the best example of a timber-framed building in Wales. It had a small hall and a great hall, showing that the family living there must have been important.It was a one- storey house. The oak beams in the attic are still blackened by smoke from the fire, which was on the floor in the middle of the house.It is a cruck house because it has cruck beams which are curved beams going from the roof to the floor.In 1636 a minstrel gallery was put into the great hall, with stairs going up to it.The house was a courthouse, where sheep-stealers were tried. From Bryndraenog the guilty prisoners were taken to the gaol at Pantycaragle, a quarter of a mile away, through an underground tunnel, which has not yet been found.
